page.title: 14Historical sites near Golden
page.content: {Golden Manor}is first recorded in 1329 as Wolvedon. When John Wolvedon died in 1524 his son-in-law John Tregian became the owner of the house. His son Francis Tregian was responsible in 1577 for hiding Cuthbert Mayne, a catholic priest. When the priest was found Francis was imprisoned and Mayne was hung, drawn and quartered. Opposite the Manor there is a dairy farm. There are medieval buildings at Golden including a milking parlour that occupies what may be a chapel which had a hammer-beam roof until it was removed a few years ago. {Golden Keep}(Gatehouse). This has an extremely rare brick pattern that may be unique in Cornwall on one of its walls. There are also two ice houses which may have also served as Mayne's hiding place. The spring marked on the OS map(921468) is supposed to be holy.
